text:
- [Sohaib] Hi, my name is
Sohaib Katariwala and I am

an Analytics Specialist
Solutions Architect with AWS.
Today I'll be walking you through some of
the new user experience improvements
on the Amazon Redshift Query Editor v2.

First, I will connect
to my Amazon Redshift
serverless work group.
Next to the work group or cluster name,
I can click on the context menu

and see the option to edit
my existing connection,
edit tags, see the connection details,
or delete the connection.
I'll create a new tab

by clicking on the plus
icon and select editor.

I can also choose to open
a notebook tab if I prefer.

In my new editor tab,
I'll write a sequel query.
I'll right-click on the tab
to rename it to something that describes
my query a little bit better.

I can also close this tab,
close all the other tabs,
close the ones on the right or the left,
or close all the tabs including this one
with a single click.

In the query editor, I
now have an expand button.

If I click it, it hides
the navigation pane.
And I can see the query editor
in a full screen view

and I can click that again to
go back to the normal view.
I can choose to minimize
and maximize the navigation pane
by using the arrow button.
I can also use the slider to increase
or decrease the navigation pane size
to my desired preference.
I can also use the keyboard shortcut
Command + B for Mac
or Control + B for Windows
to toggle the navigation pane.

Next, if I wrote a query
in my query editor,

I can see the results
area as visible below.
I can choose to minimize the results area
using the arrow button,

and I can also maximize
it with the same button.
I can also use the slider

to increase or decrease
the results pane size
to my desired preference.

Now if I want to see the
results pane in detail,
I can click on the expand button
to maximize the results pane.

And I can see all the
results in full screen mode.

This is helpful for when
I use the charts feature
to visualize the results of my query
and quickly look for some patterns.

I can use that button to
exit the full screen mode
for the results pane.
If I want to focus on query editing,
the same toggles are also there
for the query editor area.
I can maximize the editor pane

and get rid of the results
and the navigation pane
and I can go back to normal view again
with the same button.
That sums up the overview
of the new user experience improvements
on the Query Editor v2.
Thank you so much for watching.
